> meanwhil a widespread spirit of dissatisfact with the new raj was daili grow and on everi hand in the bazaar mutter of troubl began topg 163 be heard 
> the young ruler had prove to be a mere puppet in the hand of his mother and uncl who had not hesit to advanc their baseborn relat and associ to place of highest honour and emolu therebi give grievous offenc among the famili of proud and ancient lineag both hindu and moslem which had hitherto suppli the princip offic of state and had been the real buttress of the throne 
> then to fill full the measur of discont came omin rumour that the princ although still a mere youth had like his father becom addict to the use of bhang and strong wine and encourag by a worthless follow was abandon himself to all manner of expens debaucheri

> but as shir jumla khan grew rich in possess and in power—for score of fight men from afar were attract to his service—at the same time did his posit among the tribesmen becom one of increas isol

> now while it is true that modern astronomi has supersed the ancient system and peopl have ceas to believ that the star are interven in mundan affair noth could be further from the truth than the assert that astronomi has shatter the fallaci of astrolog and those of our reader who will accord to this work an unprejud perus can hard fail to be convinc that a larg major of the peopl of christendom are domin as much by these fallaci as were our pagan ancestry—th onli differ be a chang of name 
> the dogmat element of religion which was ancient design as astrolog is now known as theolog 
> all the evid bear upon the subject indic that the founder of the primari form of religion were a sect of philosoph known as magi or wise men of the aryan race of central asia who have live age befor ani concept of the supernatur had obtain in the world and specul relat to the begin of thing were necessarili confin to the contempl and studi of natur the element of which they believ to be selfexist and endless in durat but be wholli without knowledg of her inher forc they explain her manifold process by conceiv the idea that she was anim by a great and inher soul or spirit eman from which impress all her part with life and motion 
> thus endow man and other anim with soul eman alik from the imaginari great soul of natur they believ and taught that immedi after death all soul were absorb into their sourc where as the dewdrop slip into the shine sea all person ident was forev lost 
> henc we see that although recogn the soul as immort consid it not as an entiti exist independ of matter but as the spirit of matter itself the primari religion was the expon of the purest form of materi

> base the religion they institut upon their system of allegor astronomi and make it personif the object of worship they thus origin the anthropomorph or manlik god and claim to have compos them under the inspir of these self same divin they design them as sacr record or scriptur and taught the ignor mass that they were liter histori and their personif real personag who have onc live upon earth and for the good of mankind perform the wondrous work imput to them were then in heaven whenc they came 
> thus we see that the primari religion which is popular known as pagan was found in the worship of personifi natur that accord special homag to the imaginari genii of the star and inculc suprem ador to the divin suppos to resid in the sun it was ancient known by the general name of astrolatri and by the more specif one of solar worship and that it founder arrog to themselv the titl of astrolog gave to it dogmat element the name of astrolog 
> in studi the primit form of religion it will be found that none of them taught anyth relat to a futur life for the simpl reason that their founder had no concept of such a state

> at the begin of the christian era there were still in exist a sect of jew known as sadduce who were strict adher to the primit form of worship and their belief relat to the state of the dead we find record in ecclesiast xii 7 which read then shall the dust return to earth as it was and the spirit shall return to god who gave it 
> for age the doctrin of soul absorpt immedi after death constitut the belief of mankind but ultim recogn the fact that the tempor punish of the exist law were wholli inadequ to the prevent of crime and conceiv the idea that the ignor and vicious mass could be govern with a surer hand by appeal to the sentiment of hope and fear in relat to the reward and punish of an imaginari futur life the ancient astrolog resolv to remodel the dogmat element of religion so as to includ that doctrin

> as they were the sole custodian of the scriptur they made do chang in their verbiag but ad the doctrin of futur reward and punish to that written and open taught system of faith known as the exoter creed they made it the more impress by institut a system of impos rite and ceremoni which they design as mysteri into which they initi the neophyt and in which were portray in the most vivid manner the reward and punish of the imaginari futur life which they taught were the award of the god for the observ or violat of the law

< thu were the votari of the ancient astral worship divid into two distinct class the esoter or gnostic and the exoter or agnost the former compris those who knew that the god were mythic and the scriptur allegor and the latter those who were taught that the god were real and the scriptur histor or in other word it wa philosophi for the cultur few and religion for the ignor multitud 
< the initi into the secret of these two system recogn them as the two gospel and paul must have had refer to them in hi epistl to the galatian ii 2 where he distinguish the gospel which he preach on ordinari occas from that gospel which he preach privat to them which were of reput 
< such wa the system of astrolatri which origin in the orient and becom after be remodel in egypt the prototyp of all occident form of worship wa recogn success as the state religion of the grecian and roman empir and we propos to describ the erron system of natur upon which it wa base and to develop the origin of it cycl dogma ordin anniversari personif and symbol with the view to prove that it wa the veri same system which wa ultim perpetu under the name of christian

> thus were the votari of the ancient astral worship divid into two distinct class the esoter or gnostic and the exoter or agnost the former compris those who knew that the god were mythic and the scriptur allegor and the latter those who were taught that the god were real and the scriptur histor or in other word it was philosophi for the cultur few and religion for the ignor multitud 
> the initi into the secret of these two system recogn them as the two gospel and paul must have had refer to them in his epistl to the galatian ii 2 where he distinguish the gospel which he preach on ordinari occas from that gospel which he preach privat to them which were of reput 
> such was the system of astrolatri which origin in the orient and becom after be remodel in egypt the prototyp of all occident form of worship was recogn success as the state religion of the grecian and roman empir and we propos to describ the erron system of natur upon which it was base and to develop the origin of it cycl dogma ordin anniversari personif and symbol with the view to prove that it was the veri same system which was ultim perpetu under the name of christian

> recent research among the ruin of ancient citi have develop the fact that sever centuri befor the begin of our era the astronom had invent the telescop and discov the true or heliocentr system of natur but for the reason that religion had been base upon the fals or geocentr system it was deem prudent not to teach it to the mass 
> henc hide it away among the other secret of the esoter philosophi the knowledg of it was lost dure the middl age and when rediscov the hierarchi of the church of rome upon the plea that it was contrari to the teach of scriptur resort to inquisitori tortur to suppress it promulg but in spite of all their effort it has been univers accept and in this otherwis enlighten age we have present to us the anomali of a religion base upon a fals system of astronomi while it votari believ in the true system

> to mark the height to which the water should rise to secur an abund harvest post were plant upon it bank to which cross beam were attach thus ┼ 
> if the water should rise to the design height it was call the water of life or river of life and ultim this form of the cross was adopt as the symbol of the life to come or etern life and the ancient astrolog had it engrav upon stone encircl with a hieroglyph inscript to that effect one of which was discov in the ruin of the templ erect at alexandria and dedic to our lord and saviour serapi 
> but if the water fail to rise to the requir height and the horror of starvat becom the inevit result it was the custom of the peopl to nail to these cross symbol personif of the demon of famin 
> to indic the steril of the domain over which he reign he was repres by the figur of a lean and haggard man with a crown of thorn upon his head a reed cut from the river bank was place in his hand as his unreal sceptr and consid the inhabit of judea as the most slavish and meanspirit race in their knowledg they placard this figur with the inscript this is the king of the jew 
> thus to the ancient egyptian this sign of the cross was bless or accurs as it was repres with or without this figur suspend upon it 
> when the roman or modern form of christian was institut the hieroglyph inscript signifi the life to come or etern life was substitut by a placard nail to the cross with the letter i n r i inscrib upon it which are the initi of the latin word convey the same mean 
> but if we would learn how the figur of a man came to be suspend upon this form of the cross we must refer to mediaev histori which teach that in the year 680 under the pontif of agathon and dure the reign of constantin pogonat at the sixth council of the church and third at constantinopl it was order in canon 82 that instead of a lamb the figur of a man nail to a cross should be the distinguish symbol of the christian religion 
> now as this figur is repres by that of a lean and haggard man with a crown of thorn upon his head doe it not look as if the old egyptian demon of famin was the model after which it was construct

< in thi system it wa taught that the soul of the two extrem of societi constitut of the righteou and the great sinner would be consign immedi after the first judgment the one to the elysium and the other to the phlegethon where they were to remain until the second or gener judgment while the soul of less venial sinner constitut the greater mass of mankind befor be permit to enter the elysium would be compel to suffer the expiatori punish of the metempsychosi or in the upper region or smoki row of the tartaru

> this imaginari region known to the egyptian as the amenti to the greek as hade and to the hebrew as sheol was divid by an impass gulf into the two state of happi and miseri which were design in the grecian mytholog as the elysium or elysian field and the tartarus 
> in the lower part of the latter was locat the phlegethon or lake of fire and brimston the smoke from which ascend into an upper apart 
> in this system it was taught that the soul of the two extrem of societi constitut of the righteous and the great sinner would be consign immedi after the first judgment the one to the elysium and the other to the phlegethon where they were to remain until the second or general judgment while the soul of less venial sinner constitut the greater mass of mankind befor be permit to enter the elysium would be compel to suffer the expiatori punish of the metempsychosi or in the upper region or smoki row of the tartarus

< now from the project of the astrolog scienc we are assur that the last half of the grand cycl of 12000 year which wa allot to man as the durat of hi race on earth wa made to begin at a time correspond to the autumn equinox when that cardin point wa pass out of the sign of virgo and that of necess it had to come to an end at a time correspond to the vernal equinox when that cardin point wa pass out of the sign of ari from which we know whi at the last judgment the offic of trumpet wa assign to the archangel gabriel the geniu of spring and whi it wa a ram horn with which he wa to toot the crack o doom

> that the origin version of the new testament was compos when the vernal equinox was in the sign of ari we are assur by reason of the fact that it inculc homag to the lord under the symbol of the lamb and that it was dure the last or 30th degre of that sign can readili be proven by appeal to histori and to astronomi the former of which teach that the jew were remov from judea to alexandria twentyf year befor the access to the throne of philadelphus the second ptolemi to whom we have refer in our preced articl and who after reign thirtynin year die 246 year befor the begin of our era 
> by refer to the celesti atlas we will find that the vernal equinox will pass out of the sign of pisc into that of aquarius or in the year 1900 and we have but to deduct that period of time from 2150 the number of year requir for the cardin point to pass through one whole sign to determin that the spring equinox pass out of the sign of ari into that of pisc 250 year befor the begin of our era or about 2100 year ago 
> now from the project of the astrolog scienc we are assur that the last half of the grand cycl of 12000 year which was allot to man as the durat of his race on earth was made to begin at a time correspond to the autumn equinox when that cardin point was pass out of the sign of virgo and that of necess it had to come to an end at a time correspond to the vernal equinox when that cardin point was pass out of the sign of ari from which we know whi at the last judgment the offic of trumpet was assign to the archangel gabriel the genius of spring and whi it was a ram horn with which he was to toot the crack o doom 
> when the time arriv for the fulfil of the propheci we can well imagin that fear the wrath of the lamb there were weep wail and gnash of teeth among the terrorstricken sinner while those who believ they had made their call and elect sure were look with feverish expect for the second advent of their lord and saviour and doubtless cloth with their ascens robe they watch and wait with ear alert to hear the sound of gabriel trumpet summon the quick and the dead to the general judgment 
> but not a blast from the archangel ram horn was heard reverber along the sky no lord appear descend upon the cloud to meet the elect in the air and in the last act of the fear drama of judgment day the curtain refus to be rung down upon a burn world 
> with the nonfulfil of the propheci the more enlighten element of societi began to scoff at the priest who were temporarili demor but true to their decept instinct soon ralli with the plea of a mistak have been made in the calcul base upon the propheci they undoubt concoct scriptur to meet that veri emerg for to the taunt of the scoffer who in refer to the second advent of the lord enquir where is the sign of his come 
> for sinc the father fell asleep all thing continu as they were from the begin of creation they answer that the lord is not slack concern his promis but as a thief in the night he would soon come and all thing be fulfil

< personifi the principl of good and evil in god sol the ancient astrolog consecr the six divis of the 12000 year cycl correspond to the reproduct month of spring and summer to him as lord of good and symbol him by the constel of the zodiac in which the vernal equinox success occur as explain hereaft they dedic the six divis of that cycl correspond to the destruct month of autumn and winter to him as lord of evil and as such symbol him by the serpent mark the begin of hi reign by the constel serpen place in conjunct with the autumn equinox

> the appar retreat of the sun from the earth in winter and his return in the spring suggest the idea of a figur death and resurrect of the genius of that luminari they appli these phenomena of the year to man and compos the allegori relat to his fall and redempt as inculc in the exoter creed 
> in the allegori relat to the fall it was taught that after make the first human pair the lord of good or the lord god place them in a beauti garden—correspond to the season of fruit and flower or month of spring and summer with the injunct under a penalti not to eat of the fruit of a certain tree 
> when the lord of evil or devil symbol by the serpent and repres by the constel serpen place in conjunct with the autumn equinox meet them on the confin of his dominion and tempt the woman and she the man they ate of the forbidden fruit thus fall from their first estat and commit the origin sin they involv the whole human race in the consequ of their disobedi 
> then the lord god pronounc a curs against the serpent cloth the man and woman with skin to protect them against the inclem of his dominion as lord of evil and drove them from the garden after which they were necessit to earn their bread by till the ground 
> in refer to the plan of redempt the ancient astrolog divid the 6000 year appropri to man as the durat of his race on earth into ten equal cycl and taught that at the conclus of each god sol as lord of good would manifest himself in the flesh to destroy his work as lord of evil and through suffer and death make an aton for sin 
> thus have origin the doctrin of origin sin incarn and vicari aton as part of the plan of redempt and make it final correspond in point of time to the conclus of the 12000 year cycl their successor in the priest offic ultim inculc the addit dogma of the general judgment and futur reward and punish as we have shown in our introduct 
> have base the fabl of the fall and redempt of man upon the idea that he was impel without his volit to pass from the dominion of god to that of the devil or in other word upon his subject to the inexor necess which make the inclement season of autumn and winter succeed the benefic one of spring and summer it author compos the origin of the text which found in roman viii 20 read that the creatur was made subject to vaniti evil not will but by reason of him who hath subject the same in hope

< henc the 25th of march without regard to the day of the week wa celebr as the anniversari of the vernal resurrect 
< on the morn of thi day it wa the custom of the astrolog to say to the mourner assembl in the templ be of good cheer sacr band of initi your god ha risen from the dead hi pain and hi suffer shall be your salvat 
< anoth form of thi admonit quot from an ancient poem in refer to the phoenician tammuz read as follow trust ye saint your god restor trust ye in your risen lord for the pain which he endur your salvat hath procur 
< then would begin the festiv of easter which corrupt from eostr and deriv from the teuton mytholog wa one of the mani name given to the goddess of spring 
< in the observ of thi festiv the templ were adorn with floral offer the hilari sang their joy lay the fire upon the pyre or the firealtar were extinguish and rekindl with new fire or sacr fire of the star which the astrolog taught wa brought down from heaven by the wing geniu perseu the constel which ancient wa in conjunct with the vernal equinox paschal candl lit from the new fire were distribut to the faith and the paschal feast easter feast or the feast of the passov wa eaten in commemor of the passion of the incarn saviour or in other word of the passag of the sun across the celesti equat 
< in ultracathol countri the descent of the sacr fire is repres by some secretli arrang pyrotechni and the credul laiti believ they have wit a miracul display eagerli solicit paschal candl lit from it and in imit of the ancient festiv in honor of the return of spring all cathol church and most of protest one are adorn with flower the bell ring out their merriest peal and gloria in excelsi and other jubil song similar to the lay of the ancient hilari are sung

> henc the 25th of march without regard to the day of the week was celebr as the anniversari of the vernal resurrect 
> on the morn of this day it was the custom of the astrolog to say to the mourner assembl in the templ be of good cheer sacr band of initi your god has risen from the dead his pain and his suffer shall be your salvat 
> anoth form of this admonit quot from an ancient poem in refer to the phoenician tammuz read as follow trust ye saint your god restor trust ye in your risen lord for the pain which he endur your salvat hath procur 
> then would begin the festiv of easter which corrupt from eostr and deriv from the teuton mytholog was one of the mani name given to the goddess of spring 
> in the observ of this festiv the templ were adorn with floral offer the hilari sang their joy lay the fire upon the pyre or the firealtar were extinguish and rekindl with new fire or sacr fire of the star which the astrolog taught was brought down from heaven by the wing genius perseus the constel which ancient was in conjunct with the vernal equinox paschal candl lit from the new fire were distribut to the faith and the paschal feast easter feast or the feast of the passov was eaten in commemor of the passion of the incarn saviour or in other word of the passag of the sun across the celesti equat

> in the chaldean allegori the name of michael was given to this personif and call michaelma or feast of michael

> thus we have shown that the anniversari of the ancient astral worship were all fix and from church histori we learn that they were so observ by the christian until the council of nice in the year 325 when the bishop assembl at that celebr convoc desir to have the festiv of easter celebr on sunday which had been made the sabbath by the edict of constantin in the year 321 order that it should be observ on the sunday of the full moon which come on or next after the vernal equinox

> have shown that the founder of the ancient astrolatri accord homag to god sol as lord of evil under the symbol of the serpent and mark the begin of his reign as such by the constel serpen place in conjunct with the autumn equinox we will now direct attent to the symbol under which he was worship as lord of good which correspond to the form of the constel in which occur the vernal equinox and which was chang to correspond to the form of the succeed constel as that cardin point pass into it by that process known in astronomi as the precess of the equinox it explan becom essenti to a correct understand of our subject 
> after long observ aid by the telescop of which they were undoubt the origin inventor the ancient astrolog discov that the sun in make his appar annual revolut did not return to the same point in the heaven but fell behind that of the preced year at the rate of 50� second of a degre annual 
> at this rate of precess which modern calcul has confirm it requir 71 23 year for the cardin point to pass through one degre on the eclipt and 2150 year through thirti degre or one sign of the zodiac 
> the knowledg of this process afford an exact chronolog we are enabl not onli to determin the origin of these symbol but to approxim veri near to the respect date of their adopt

> this symbol is still retain in the cathol church

< he had the honour of knighthood confer upon him by hi most sacr majesti and wa sequestr as a malign by the parliament 1642 and afterward as a resolution in the year 1648’ these two crossgrain epithet of malign and resolution cost poor sir allan one half of the famili estat 
< hi son denni bertram marri a daughter of an emin fanat who had a seat in the council of state and save by that union the remaind of the famili properti 
< but as ill chanc would have it he becam enamour of the lady’ principl as well as of her charm and my author give him thi charact ‘he wa a man of emin part and resolut for which reason he wa chosen by the western counti one of the committe of noblemen and gentlemen to report their grief to the privi council of charl ii

> he had the honour of knighthood confer upon him by his most sacr majesti and was sequestr as a malign by the parliament 1642 and afterward as a resolution in the year 1648’ these two crossgrain epithet of malign and resolution cost poor sir allan one half of the famili estat

> the apprize therefor as the holder of a mortgag was then call enter upon possess and in the languag of hotspur ‘came me crank in’ and cut the famili out of anoth monstrous cantl of their remain properti

< he turn out of door the reverend aaron macbriar hi mother’ chaplain it is said they quarrel about the good grace of a milkmaid drank himself daili drunk with brim health to the king council and bishop held orgi with the laird of lagg theophilu oglethorp and sir jame turner and lastli took hi grey geld and join claver at killiecranki 
< at the skirmish of dunkeld 1689 he wa shot dead by a cameronian with a silver button be suppos to have proof from the evil one against lead and steel and hi grave is still call the wick laird’ lair 
< hi son lewi had more prudenc than seem usual to have belong to the famili 
< he nurs what properti wa yet left to him for donohoe’ excess as well as fine and forfeitur had made anoth inroad upon the estat 
< and although even he did not escap the fatal which induc the laird of ellangowan to interfer with polit he had yet the prudenc ere he went out with lord kenmor in 1715 to convey hi estat to truste in order to parri pain and penalti in case the earl of mar could not put down the protest success 
< but scylla and charybdisa word to the wiseh onli save hi estat at expens of a lawsuit which again subdivid the famili properti 
< he wa howev a man of resolut

> he turn out of door the reverend aaron macbriar his mother’ chaplain it is said they quarrel about the good grace of a milkmaid drank himself daili drunk with brim health to the king council and bishop held orgi with the laird of lagg theophilus oglethorp and sir jame turner and last took his grey geld and join claver at killiecranki 
> at the skirmish of dunkeld 1689 he was shot dead by a cameronian with a silver button be suppos to have proof from the evil one against lead and steel and his grave is still call the wick laird’ lair 
> his son lewi had more prudenc than seem usual to have belong to the famili 
> he nurs what properti was yet left to him for donohoe’ excess as well as fine and forfeitur had made anoth inroad upon the estat 
> and although even he did not escap the fatal which induc the laird of ellangowan to interfer with polit he had yet the prudenc ere he went out with lord kenmor in 1715 to convey his estat to truste in order to parri pain and penalti in case the earl of mar could not put down the protest success 
> but scylla and charybdisa word to the wiseh onli save his estat at expens of a lawsuit which again subdivid the famili properti 
> he was howev a man of resolut 
1260,1270c1260,1270
< thi wa the new place of ellangowan in which we left our hero better amus perhap than our reader and to thi lewi bertram retreat full of project for reestablish the prosper of hi famili 
< he took some land into hi own hand rent some from neighbour proprietor bought and sold highland cattl and cheviot sheep rode to fair and tryst fought hard bargain and held necess at the staff’ end as well as he might 
< but what he gain in purs he lost in honour for such agricultur and commerci negoti were veri ill look upon by hi brother laird who mind noth but cockfight hunt cours and horserac with now and then the altern of a desper duel 
< the occup which he follow encroach in their opinion upon the articl of ellangowan’ gentri and he found it necessari gradual to estrang himself from their societi and sink into what wa then a veri ambigu charact a gentleman farmer 
< in the midst of hi scheme death claim hi tribut and the scanti remain of a larg properti descend upon godfrey bertram the present possessor hi onli son 
< the danger of the father’ specul wa soon seen 
< depriv of laird lewis’ person and activ superintend all hi undertak miscarri and becam either abort or peril 
< without a singl spark of energi to meet or repel these misfortun godfrey put hi faith in the activ of anoth 
< he kept neither hunter nor hound nor ani other southern preliminari to ruin but as ha been observ of hi countrymen he kept a man of busi who answer the purpos equal well 
< under thi gentleman’ supervis small debt grew into larg interest were accumul upon capit movabl bond becam herit and law charg were heap upon all though ellangowan possess so littl the spirit of a litig that he wa on two occas charg to make payment of the expens of a long lawsuit although he had never befor heard that he had such case in court 
< meanwhil hi neighbour predict hi final ruin 
---
> this was the new place of ellangowan in which we left our hero better amus perhap than our reader and to this lewi bertram retreat full of project for reestablish the prosper of his famili 
> he took some land into his own hand rent some from neighbour proprietor bought and sold highland cattl and cheviot sheep rode to fair and tryst fought hard bargain and held necess at the staff’ end as well as he might 
> but what he gain in purs he lost in honour for such agricultur and commerci negoti were veri ill look upon by his brother laird who mind noth but cockfight hunt cours and horserac with now and then the altern of a desper duel 
> the occup which he follow encroach in their opinion upon the articl of ellangowan’ gentri and he found it necessari gradual to estrang himself from their societi and sink into what was then a veri ambigu charact a gentleman farmer 
> in the midst of his scheme death claim his tribut and the scanti remain of a larg properti descend upon godfrey bertram the present possessor his onli son 
> the danger of the father’ specul was soon seen 
> depriv of laird lewis’ person and activ superintend all his undertak miscarri and becam either abort or peril 
> without a singl spark of energi to meet or repel these misfortun godfrey put his faith in the activ of anoth 
> he kept neither hunter nor hound nor ani other southern preliminari to ruin but as has been observ of his countrymen he kept a man of busi who answer the purpos equal well 
> under this gentleman’ supervis small debt grew into larg interest were accumul upon capit movabl bond becam herit and law charg were heap upon all though ellangowan possess so littl the spirit of a litig that he was on two occas charg to make payment of the expens of a long lawsuit although he had never befor heard that he had such case in court 
> meanwhil his neighbour predict his final ruin

> among those who cherish this imaginari privileg with undoubt faith was an old clergyman with whom manner was place dure his youth

> his pupil in earli youth natur caught some portion of his enthusiasm and labour for a time to make himself master of the technic process of astrolog research so that befor he becam convinc of it absurd william lilli himself would have allow him ‘a curious fanci and pierc judgment in resolv a question of nativity’ on the present occas he aros as earli in the morn as the short of the day permit and proceed to calcul the nativ of the young heir of ellangowan

< it wa somewhat remark that manner had onc befor tri a similar piec of fooleri at the instanc of sophia wellwood the young ladi to whom he wa attach and that a similar conjunct of planetari influenc threaten her with death or imprison in her thirtyninth year 
< she wa at thi time eighteen so that accord to the result of the scheme in both case the same year threaten her with the same misfortun that wa presag to the nativ or infant whom that night had introduc into the world

> mar have digniti in the cusp of the twelfth hous threaten captiv or sudden and violent death to the nativ and manner have recours to those further rule by which divin pretend to ascertain the vehem of this evil direct observ from the result that three period would be particular hazardoushi fifth his tenth his twentyfirst year 
> it was somewhat remark that manner had onc befor tri a similar piec of fooleri at the instanc of sophia wellwood the young ladi to whom he was attach and that a similar conjunct of planetari influenc threaten her with death or imprison in her thirtyninth year 
> she was at this time eighteen so that accord to the result of the scheme in both case the same year threaten her with the same misfortun that was presag to the nativ or infant whom that night had introduc into the world 
> struck with this coincid manner repeat his calcul and the result approxim the event predict until at length the same month and day of the month seem assign as the period of peril to both 
> it will be readili believ that in mention this circumst we lay no weight whatev upon the pretend inform thus convey 
> but it often happen such is our natur love for the marvel that we will contribut our own effort to beguil our better judgment

> the rest of the day which manner by mr bertram’ invit spent at ellangowan pass over without anyth remark and on the morn of that which follow the travel mount his palfrey bade a courteous adieu to his hospit landlord and to his cleric attend repeat his good wish for the prosper of the famili and then turn his horse’ head toward england disappear from the sight of the inmat of ellangowan

> chapter vi next the justic in fair round belli with good capon line with eye sever and beard of formal cut full of wise saw and modern instanc and so he play his part as you like it when mrs bertram of ellangowan was abl to hear the news of what had pass dure her confin her apart rung with all manner of gossip respect the handsom young student from oxford who had told such a fortun by the star to the young laird ‘bless on his dainti face’ the form accent and manner of the stranger were expati upon 
> his hors bridl saddl and stirrup did not remain unnot 
> all this made a great impress upon the mind of mrs bertram for the good ladi had no small store of superstit 
> her first employ when she becam capabl of a littl work was to make a small velvet bag for the scheme of nativ which she had obtain from her husband 
1459,1469c1459,1469
< the whole wa then put into the velvet bag aforesaid and hung as a charm round the neck of the infant where hi mother resolv it should remain until the period for the legitim satisfact of her curios should arriv 
< the father also resolv to do hi part by the child in secur him a good educ and with the view that it should commenc with the first dawn of reason domini sampson wa easili induc to renounc hi public profess of parish schoolmast make hi constant resid at the place and in consider of a sum not quit equal to the wage of a footman even at that time to undertak to commun to the futur laird of ellangowan all the erudit which he had and all the grace and accomplish whichh had not inde but which he had never discov that he want 
< in thi arrang the laird found also hi privat advantag secur the constant benefit of a patient auditor to whom he told hi stori when they were alon and at whose expens he could break a sli jest when he had compani 
< about four year after thi time a great commot took place in the counti where ellangowan is situat 
< those who watch the sign of the time had long been of opinion that a chang of ministri wa about to take place and at length after a due proport of hope fear and delay rumour from good author and bad author and no author at all after some club had drank up with thi statesman and other down with him after ride and run and post and address and counteraddress and proffer of live and fortun the blow wa at length struck the administr of the day wa dissolv and parliament as a natur consequ wa dissolv also 
< sir thoma kittlecourt like other member in the same situat post down to hi counti and met but an indiffer recept 
< he wa a partizan of the old administr and the friend of the new had alreadi set about an activ canvass in behalf of john featherhead esq who kept the best hound and hunter in the shire 
< among other who join the standard of revolt wa gilbert glossin writer in agent for the laird of ellangowan 
< thi honest gentleman had either been refus some favour by the old member or what is as probabl he had got all that he had the most distant pretens to ask and could onli look to the other side for fresh advanc 
< mr glossin had a vote upon ellangowan’ properti and he wa now determin that hi patron should have one also there be no doubt which side mr bertram would embrac in the contest 
< he easili persuad ellangowan that it would be credit to him to take the field at the head of as strong a parti as possibl and immedi went to work make vote as everi scotch lawyer know how by split and subdivid the superior upon thi ancient and onc power baroni

> the whole was then put into the velvet bag aforesaid and hung as a charm round the neck of the infant where his mother resolv it should remain until the period for the legitim satisfact of her curios should arriv 
> the father also resolv to do his part by the child in secur him a good educ and with the view that it should commenc with the first dawn of reason domini sampson was easili induc to renounc his public profess of parish schoolmast make his constant resid at the place and in consider of a sum not quit equal to the wage of a footman even at that time to undertak to communic to the futur laird of ellangowan all the erudit which he had and all the grace and accomplish whichh had not inde but which he had never discov that he want

1512,1520c1512,1520
< although the charact of those gipsi tribe which formerli inund most of the nation of europ and which in some degre still subsist among them as a distinct peopl is gener understood the reader will pardon my say a few word respect their situat in scotland 
< it is well known that the gipsi were at an earli period acknowledg as a separ and independ race by one of the scottish monarch and that they were less favour distinguish by a subsequ law which render the charact of gipsi equal in the judici balanc to that of common and habitu thief and prescrib hi punish accordingli 
< notwithstand the sever of thi and other statut the fratern prosper amid the distress of the countri and receiv larg access from among those whom famin oppress or the sword of war had depriv of the ordinari mean of subsist 
< they lost in a great measur by thi intermixtur the nation charact of egyptian and becam a mingl race have all the idl and predatori habit of their eastern ancestor with a feroc which they probabl borrow from the men of the north who join their societi 
< they travel in differ band and had rule among themselv by which each tribe wa confin to it own district 
< the slightest invas of the precinct which had been assign to anoth tribe produc desper skirmish in which there wa often much blood shed 
< the patriot fletcher of saltoun drew a pictur of these banditti about a centuri ago which my reader will perus with astonish ‘there are at thi day in scotland besid a great mani poor famili veri meanli provid for by the church box with other who by live on bad food fall into variou diseas two hundr thousand peopl beg from door to door 
< these are not onli no way advantag but a veri grievou burden to so poor a countri 
< and though the number of them be perhap doubl to what it wa formerli by reason of thi present great distress yet in all time there have been about one hundr thousand of those vagabond who have live without ani regard or subject either to the law of the land or even those of god and natur

> although the charact of those gipsi tribe which former inund most of the nation of europ and which in some degre still subsist among them as a distinct peopl is general understood the reader will pardon my say a few word respect their situat in scotland 
> it is well known that the gipsi were at an earli period acknowledg as a separ and independ race by one of the scottish monarch and that they were less favour distinguish by a subsequ law which render the charact of gipsi equal in the judici balanc to that of common and habitu thief and prescrib his punish accord 
> notwithstand the sever of this and other statut the fratern prosper amid the distress of the countri and receiv larg access from among those whom famin oppress or the sword of war had depriv of the ordinari mean of subsist 
> they lost in a great measur by this intermixtur the nation charact of egyptian and becam a mingl race have all the idl and predatori habit of their eastern ancestor with a feroc which they probabl borrow from the men of the north who join their societi 
> they travel in differ band and had rule among themselv by which each tribe was confin to it own district 
> the slightest invas of the precinct which had been assign to anoth tribe produc desper skirmish in which there was often much blood shed 
> the patriot fletcher of saltoun drew a pictur of these banditti about a centuri ago which my reader will perus with astonish ‘there are at this day in scotland besid a great mani poor famili veri mean provid for by the church box with other who by live on bad food fall into various diseas two hundr thousand peopl beg from door to door 
> these are not onli no way advantag but a veri grievous burden to so poor a countri 
> and though the number of them be perhap doubl to what it was former by reason of this present great distress yet in all time there have been about one hundr thousand of those vagabond who have live without ani regard or subject either to the law of the land or even those of god and natur

< the commun of derncleugh who care for no rogu but their own were wholli without alarm at the sever of the justice’ proceed toward other itiner

< to thi there wa no repli for the fact wa too evid and well known

1564,1571c1564,1571
< on the other side for uniformity’ sake wa a precautionari annunci of springgun and mantrap of such formid power that said the rubrick with an emphat nota bene’if a man goe in they will break a horse’ leg’ in defianc of these threat six wellgrown gipsi boy and girl were ride cockhors upon the new gate and plait mayflow which it wa but too evid had been gather within the forbidden precinct 
< with as much anger as he wa capabl of feel or perhap of assum the laird command them to descendthey paid no attent to hi mandat he then began to pull them down one after anotherthey resist passiv at least each sturdi bronz varlet make himself as heavi as he could or climb up as fast as he wa dismount 
< the laird then call in the assist of hi servant a surli fellow who had immedi recours to hi horsewhip 
< a few lash sent the parti ascamp and thu commenc the first breach of the peac between the hous of ellangowan and the gipsi of derncleugh 
< the latter could not for some time imagin that the war wa real until they found that their children were horsewhip by the griev when found trespass that their ass were poind by the groundoffic when left in the plantat or even when turn to graze by the roadsid against the provis of the turnpik act that the constabl began to make curiou inquiri into their mode of gain a livelihood and express hi surpris that the men should sleep in the hovel all day and be abroad the greater part of the night 
< when matter came to thi point the gipsi without scrupl enter upon measur of retali 
< ellangowan’ henroost were plunder hi linen stolen from the line or bleachingground hi fish poach hi dog kidnap hi grow tree cut or bark 
< much petti mischief wa done and some evid for the mischief’ sake 
---
> on the other side for uniformity’ sake was a precautionari annunci of springgun and mantrap of such formid power that said the rubrick with an emphat nota bene’if a man goe in they will break a horse’ leg’ in defianc of these threat six wellgrown gipsi boy and girl were ride cockhors upon the new gate and plait mayflow which it was but too evid had been gather within the forbidden precinct 
> with as much anger as he was capabl of feel or perhap of assum the laird command them to descendthey paid no attent to his mandat he then began to pull them down one after anotherthey resist passiv at least each sturdi bronz varlet make himself as heavi as he could or climb up as fast as he was dismount 
> the laird then call in the assist of his servant a sur fellow who had immedi recours to his horsewhip 
> a few lash sent the parti ascamp and thus commenc the first breach of the peac between the hous of ellangowan and the gipsi of derncleugh 
> the latter could not for some time imagin that the war was real until they found that their children were horsewhip by the griev when found trespass that their ass were poind by the groundoffic when left in the plantat or even when turn to graze by the roadsid against the provis of the turnpik act that the constabl began to make curious inquiri into their mode of gain a livelihood and express his surpris that the men should sleep in the hovel all day and be abroad the greater part of the night 
> when matter came to this point the gipsi without scrupl enter upon measur of retali 
> ellangowan’ henroost were plunder his linen stolen from the line or bleachingground his fish poach his dog kidnap his grow tree cut or bark 
> much petti mischief was done and some evid for the mischief’ sake

1578,1596c1578,1596
< in trace the rise and progress of the scottish maroon war we must not omit to mention that year had roll on and that littl harri bertram one of the hardiest and most live children that ever made a sword and grenadier’ cap of rush now approach hi fifth revolv birthday 
< a hardihood of disposit which earli develop itself made him alreadi a littl wander he wa well acquaint with everi patch of lea ground and dingl around ellangowan and could tell in hi broken languag upon what baulk grew the bonniest flower and what cops had the ripest nut 
< he repeatedli terrifi hi attend by clamber about the ruin of the old castl and had more than onc made a stolen excurs as far as the gipsi hamlet 
< on these occas he wa gener brought back by meg merrili who though she could not be prevail upon to enter the place of ellangowan after her nephew had been given up to the pressgang did not appar extend her resent to the child 
< on the contrari she often contriv to waylay him in hi walk sing him a gipsi song give him a ride upon her jackass and thrust into hi pocket a piec of gingerbread or a redcheek appl 
< thi woman’ ancient attach to the famili repel and check in everi other direct seem to rejoic in have some object on which it could yet repos and expand itself 
< she prophesi a hundr time ‘that young mr harri would be the pride o’ the famili and there hadna been sic a sprout frae the auld aik sinc the death of arthur macdingawai that wa kill in the battl o’ the bloodi bay as for the present stick it wa good for noth but firewood’ on one occas when the child wa ill she lay all night below the window chant a rhyme which she believ sovereign as a febrifug and could neither be prevail upon to enter the hous nor to leav the station she had chosen till she wa inform that the crisi wa over 
< the affect of thi woman becam matter of suspicion not inde to the laird who wa never hasti in suspect evil but to hi wife who had indiffer health and poor spirit 
< she wa now far advanc in a second pregnanc and as she could not walk abroad herself and the woman who attend upon harri wa young and thoughtless she pray domini sampson to undertak the task of watch the boy in hi rambl when he should not be otherwis accompani 
< the domini love hi young charg and wa enraptur with hi own success in have alreadi brought him so far in hi learn as to spell word of three syllabl 
< the idea of thi earli prodigi of erudit be carri off by the gipsi like a second adam smithfootnot the father of econom philosophi wa when a child actual carri off by gipsi and remain some hour in their possess 
< wa not to be toler and accordingli though the charg wa contrari to all hi habit of life he readili undertook it and might be seen stalk about with a mathemat problem in hi head and hi eye upon a child of five year old whose rambl led him into a hundr awkward situat 
< twice wa the domini chase by a crossgrain cow onc he fell into the brook cross at the steppingston and anoth time wa bog up to the middl in the slough of lochend in attempt to gather a waterlili for the young laird 
< it wa the opinion of the villag matron who reliev sampson on the latter occas ‘that the laird might as weel trust the care o’ hi bairn to a potato bogle’ but the good domini bore all hi disast with graviti and seren equal imperturb 
< ‘prodigious’ wa the onli ejacul they ever extort from the muchendur man 
< enlarg the laird had by thi time determin to make rootandbranch work with the maroon of derncleugh 
< the old servant shook their head at hi propos and even domini sampson ventur upon an indirect remonstr 
< as howev it wa couch in the oracular phrase ‘ne movea camerinam’ neither the allus nor the languag in which it wa express were calcul for mr bertram’ edif and matter proceed against the gipsi in form of law 
< everi door in the hamlet wa chalk by the groundoffic in token of a formal warn to remov at next term 
---
> in trace the rise and progress of the scottish maroon war we must not omit to mention that year had roll on and that littl harri bertram one of the hardiest and most live children that ever made a sword and grenadier’ cap of rush now approach his fifth revolv birthday 
> a hardihood of disposit which earli develop itself made him alreadi a littl wander he was well acquaint with everi patch of lea ground and dingl around ellangowan and could tell in his broken languag upon what baulk grew the bonniest flower and what cops had the ripest nut 
> he repeat terrifi his attend by clamber about the ruin of the old castl and had more than onc made a stolen excurs as far as the gipsi hamlet 
> on these occas he was general brought back by meg merrili who though she could not be prevail upon to enter the place of ellangowan after her nephew had been given up to the pressgang did not appar extend her resent to the child 
> on the contrari she often contriv to waylay him in his walk sing him a gipsi song give him a ride upon her jackass and thrust into his pocket a piec of gingerbread or a redcheek appl 
> this woman’ ancient attach to the famili repel and check in everi other direct seem to rejoic in have some object on which it could yet repos and expand itself 
> she prophesi a hundr time ‘that young mr harri would be the pride o’ the famili and there hadna been sic a sprout frae the auld aik sinc the death of arthur macdingawai that was kill in the battl o’ the bloodi bay as for the present stick it was good for noth but firewood’ on one occas when the child was ill she lay all night below the window chant a rhyme which she believ sovereign as a febrifug and could neither be prevail upon to enter the hous nor to leav the station she had chosen till she was inform that the crisi was over 
> the affect of this woman becam matter of suspicion not inde to the laird who was never hasti in suspect evil but to his wife who had indiffer health and poor spirit 
> she was now far advanc in a second pregnanc and as she could not walk abroad herself and the woman who attend upon harri was young and thoughtless she pray domini sampson to undertak the task of watch the boy in his rambl when he should not be otherwis accompani 
> the domini love his young charg and was enraptur with his own success in have alreadi brought him so far in his learn as to spell word of three syllabl 
> the idea of this earli prodigi of erudit be carri off by the gipsi like a second adam smithfootnot the father of econom philosophi was when a child actual carri off by gipsi and remain some hour in their possess 
> was not to be toler and accord though the charg was contrari to all his habit of life he readili undertook it and might be seen stalk about with a mathemat problem in his head and his eye upon a child of five year old whose rambl led him into a hundr awkward situat 
> twice was the domini chase by a crossgrain cow onc he fell into the brook cross at the steppingston and anoth time was bog up to the middl in the slough of lochend in attempt to gather a waterlili for the young laird 
> it was the opinion of the villag matron who reliev sampson on the latter occas ‘that the laird might as weel trust the care o’ his bairn to a potato bogle’ but the good domini bore all his disast with graviti and seren equal imperturb 
> ‘prodigious’ was the onli ejacul they ever extort from the muchendur man 
> enlarg the laird had by this time determin to make rootandbranch work with the maroon of derncleugh 
> the old servant shook their head at his propos and even domini sampson ventur upon an indirect remonstr 
> as howev it was couch in the oracular phrase ‘ne movea camerinam’ neither the allus nor the languag in which it was express were calcul for mr bertram’ edif and matter proceed against the gipsi in form of law 
> everi door in the hamlet was chalk by the groundoffic in token of a formal warn to remov at next term

1611,1617c1611,1617
< the road wa narrow run between two broken bank of sand and mr bertram’ servant rode forward smack hi whip with an air of author and motion to the driver to allow free passag to their better 
< hi signal wa unattend to 
< he then call to the men who loung idli on befor ‘stand to your beasts’ head and make room for the laird to pass’ ‘he shall have hi share of the road’ answer a male gipsi from under hi slouch and largebrim hat and without rais hi face ‘and he shall have nae mair the highway is as free to our cuddi as to hi gelding’ the tone of the man be sulki and even menac mr bertram thought it best to put hi digniti in hi pocket and pass by the process quietli on such space as they chose to leav for hi accommod which wa narrow enough 
< to cover with an appear of indiffer hi feel of the want of respect with which he wa treat he address one of the men as he pass him without ani show of greet salut or recognition’gil baillie’ he said ‘have you heard that your son gabriel is well’ the question respect the young man who had been press 
< ‘if i had heard otherwise’ said the old man look up with a stern and menac counten ‘you should have heard of it too’ and he plod on hi way tarri no further question

1649,1659c1649,1659
< there wa at thi period employ as a ridingoffic or supervisor in that part of the countri a certain franci kennedi alreadi name in our narrativea stout resolut and activ man who had made seizur to a great amount and wa proport hate by those who had an interest in the fair trade as they call the pursuit of these contraband adventur 
< thi person wa natur son to a gentleman of good famili owe to which circumst and to hi be of a jolli convivi disposit and sing a good song he wa admit to the occasion societi of the gentlemen of the countri and wa a member of sever of their club for practis athlet game at which he wa particularli expert 
< at ellangowan kennedi wa a frequent and alway an accept guest 
< hi vivac reliev mr bertram of the troubl of thought and the labour which it cost him to support a detail commun of idea while the dare and danger exploit which he had undertaken in the discharg of hi offic form excel convers 
< to all these revenu adventur did the laird of ellangowan serious inclin and the amus which he deriv from kennedy’ societi form an excel reason for countenanc and assist the narrat in the execut of hi invidi and hazard duti 
< ‘frank kennedy’ he said ‘wa a gentleman though on the wrang side of the blanket he wa connect with the famili of ellangowan through the hous of glengubbl 
< the last laird of glengubbl would have brought the estat into the ellangowan line but happen to go to harrig he there met with miss jean hadawaybi the by the green dragon at harrig is the best hous of the twabut for frank kennedi he’ in one sens a gentleman born and it’ a shame not to support him against these blackguard smugglers’ after thi leagu had taken place between judgment and execut it chanc that captain dirk hatteraick had land a cargo of spirit and other contraband good upon the beach not far from ellangowan and confid in the indiffer with which the laird had formerli regard similar infract of the law he wa neither veri anxiou to conceal nor to expedit the transact 
< the consequ wa that mr frank kennedi arm with a warrant from ellangowan and support by some of the laird’ peopl who knew the countri and by a parti of militari pour down upon the keg bale and bag and after a desper affray in which sever wound were given and receiv succeed in clap the broad arrow upon the articl and bear them off in triumph to the next customhous 
< dirk hatteraick vow in dutch german and english a deep and full reveng both against the gauger and hi abettor and all who knew him thought it like he would keep hi word 
< a few day after the departur of the gipsi tribe mr bertram ask hi ladi one morn at breakfast whether thi wa not littl harry’ birthday 
< ‘five year auld exactli thi bless day’ answer the ladi ‘so we may look into the english gentleman’ paper’ mr bertram like to show hi author in trifl 
---
> there was at this period employ as a ridingoffic or supervisor in that part of the countri a certain franci kennedi alreadi name in our narrativea stout resolut and activ man who had made seizur to a great amount and was proport hate by those who had an interest in the fair trade as they call the pursuit of these contraband adventur 
> this person was natur son to a gentleman of good famili owe to which circumst and to his be of a jolli convivi disposit and sing a good song he was admit to the occasion societi of the gentlemen of the countri and was a member of sever of their club for practis athlet game at which he was particular expert 
> at ellangowan kennedi was a frequent and alway an accept guest 
> his vivac reliev mr bertram of the troubl of thought and the labour which it cost him to support a detail communic of idea while the dare and danger exploit which he had undertaken in the discharg of his offic form excel convers 
> to all these revenu adventur did the laird of ellangowan serious inclin and the amus which he deriv from kennedy’ societi form an excel reason for countenanc and assist the narrat in the execut of his invidi and hazard duti 
> ‘frank kennedy’ he said ‘was a gentleman though on the wrang side of the blanket he was connect with the famili of ellangowan through the hous of glengubbl 
> the last laird of glengubbl would have brought the estat into the ellangowan line but happen to go to harrig he there met with miss jean hadawaybi the by the green dragon at harrig is the best hous of the twabut for frank kennedi he’ in one sens a gentleman born and it’ a shame not to support him against these blackguard smugglers’ after this leagu had taken place between judgment and execut it chanc that captain dirk hatteraick had land a cargo of spirit and other contraband good upon the beach not far from ellangowan and confid in the indiffer with which the laird had former regard similar infract of the law he was neither veri anxious to conceal nor to expedit the transact 
> the consequ was that mr frank kennedi arm with a warrant from ellangowan and support by some of the laird’ peopl who knew the countri and by a parti of militari pour down upon the keg bale and bag and after a desper affray in which sever wound were given and receiv succeed in clap the broad arrow upon the articl and bear them off in triumph to the next customhous 
> dirk hatteraick vow in dutch german and english a deep and full reveng both against the gauger and his abettor and all who knew him thought it like he would keep his word 
> a few day after the departur of the gipsi tribe mr bertram ask his ladi one morn at breakfast whether this was not littl harry’ birthday 
> ‘five year auld exact this bless day’ answer the ladi ‘so we may look into the english gentleman’ paper’ mr bertram like to show his author in trifl

< he had often promis the child a ride upon hi galloway and from sing danc and play punch for hi amus wa a particular favourit 
< he no sooner came scamper up the path than the boy loudli claim hi promis and kennedi who saw no risk in indulg him and wish to teas the domini in whose visag he read a remonstr caught up harri from the ground place him befor him and continu hi rout sampson’ ‘peradventur master kennedy’ be lost in the clatter of hi horse’ feet

> i’ll stand for the french articl by the time i come back and we’ll drink the young laird’ health in a bowl that would swim the collector’ yawl’ so say he mount his hors and gallop off 
> about a mile from the hous and upon the verg of the wood which as we have said cover a promontori termin in the cape call the point of warroch kennedi met young harri bertram attend by his tutor domini sampson 
> he had often promis the child a ride upon his galloway and from sing danc and play punch for his amus was a particular favourit 
> he no sooner came scamper up the path than the boy loud claim his promis and kennedi who saw no risk in indulg him and wish to teas the domini in whose visag he read a remonstr caught up harri from the ground place him befor him and continu his rout sampson’ ‘peradventur master kennedy’ be lost in the clatter of his horse’ feet 
> the pedagogu hesit a moment whether he should go after them but kennedi be a person in full confid of the famili and with whom he himself had no delight in associ ‘be that he was addict unto profan and scurril jests’ he continu his own walk at his own pace till he reach the place of ellangowan 
> the spectat from the ruin wall of the castl were still watch the sloop of war which at length but not without the loss of consider time recov searoom enough to weather the point of warroch and was lost to their sight behind that wood promontori

< a colour handkerchief which the unfortun man had worn round hi neck did not present the usual appear but wa much loosen and the knot displac and drag extrem tight the fold were also compress as if it had been use as a mean of grappl the deceas and drag him perhap to the precipic

< such wa the account given by william pritchard master and command of hi majesty’ sloop of war shark who conclud by regret deepli that he had not had the happi to fall in with the scoundrel who had had the impud to fire on hi majesty’ flag and with an assur that should he meet mr dirk hatteraick in ani futur cruis he would not fail to bring him into port under hi stern to answer whatev might be alleg against him 
< chapter xi enter time as choru i that pleas some tri all both joy and terror of good and bad that make and unfold error now take upon me in the name of time to use my wing imput it not a crime to me or my swift passag that i slide o’er sixteen year and leav the growth untri of that wide gap 
---

> chapter xi enter time as chorus i that pleas some tri all both joy and terror of good and bad that make and unfold error now take upon me in the name of time to use my wing imput it not a crime to me or my swift passag that i slide o’er sixteen year and leav the growth untri of that wide gap

< the gap is a wide one yet if the reader’ experi in life enabl him to look back on so mani year the space will scarc appear longer in hi recollect than the time consum in turn these page 
< it wa then in the month of novemb about seventeen year after the catastroph relat in the last chapter that dure a cold and stormi night a social group had close around the kitchenfir of the gordon arm at kippletringan a small but comfort inn kept by mr maccandlish in that villag

< mr maccandlish throne in a comfort easychair line with black leather wa regal herself and a neighbour gossip or two with a cup of genuin tea and at the same time keep a sharp eye upon her domest as they went and came in prosecut of their variou duti and commiss

> the gap is a wide one yet if the reader’ experi in life enabl him to look back on so mani year the space will scarc appear longer in his recollect than the time consum in turn these page 
> it was then in the month of novemb about seventeen year after the catastroph relat in the last chapter that dure a cold and stormi night a social group had close around the kitchenfir of the gordon arm at kippletringan a small but comfort inn kept by mrs maccandlish in that villag 
> the convers which pass among them will save me the troubl of tell the few event occur dure this chasm in our histori with which it is necessari that the reader should be acquaint 
> mrs maccandlish throne in a comfort easychair line with black leather was regal herself and a neighbour gossip or two with a cup of genuin tea and at the same time keep a sharp eye upon her domest as they went and came in prosecut of their various duti and commiss 
> the clerk and precentor of the parish enjoy at a littl distanc his saturday night’ pipe and aid it bland fumig by an occasion sip of brandi and water 
> deacon bearcliff a man of great import in the villag combin the indulg of both parti he had his pipe and his teacup the latter be lace with a littl spirit

1853,1864c1853,1864
< ‘a cup of your tea ma’am if you will favour me’ mr maccandlish bustl about reinforc her teapot with hyson and proceed in her duti with her best grace 
< ‘we have a veri nice parlour sir and everyth veri agreeabl for gentlefolk but it’ bespok the night for a gentleman and hi daughter that are go to leav thi part of the countri ane of my chais is gane for them and will be back forthwith 
< they’r no sae weel in the warld as they have been but we’r a’ subject to up and down in thi life as your honour must need kenbut is not the tobaccoreek disagre to your honour’ ‘bi no mean ma’am i am an old campaign and perfectli use to it 
< will you permit me to make some inquiri about a famili in thi neighbourhood’ the sound of wheel wa now heard and the landladi hurri to the door to receiv her expect guest but return in an instant follow by the postilion 
< ‘no they canna come at no rate the laird’ sae ill’ ‘but god help them’ said the landladi ‘the morn’ the term the veri last day they can bide in the hous a’ thing’ to be roupit’ ‘weel but they can come at no rate i tell ye mr bertram canna be moved’ ‘what mr bertram’ said the stranger ‘not mr bertram of ellangowan i hope’ ‘just e’en that same sir and if ye be a friend o’ hi ye have come at a time when he’ sair bested’ ‘i have been abroad for mani yearsi hi health so much deranged’ ‘ay and hi affair an’ a’’ said the deacon ‘the creditor have enter into possess o’ the estat and it’ for sale and some that made the maist by himi name nae name but mr maccandlish ken wha i mean the landladi shook her head significantlythey’r sairest on him e’en now 
< i have a sma’ matter due myself but i would rather have lost it than gane to turn the auld man out of hi hous and him just dying’ ‘ay but’ said the parish clerk ‘factor glossin want to get rid of the auld laird and drive on the sale for fear the heirmal should cast up upon them for i have heard say if there wa an heirmal they couldna sell the estat for auld ellangowan’ debt’ ‘he had a son born a good mani year ago’ said the stranger ‘he is dead i suppose’ ‘nae man can say for that’ answer the clerk mysteri 
< ‘dead’ said the deacon ‘i’s warrant him dead lang syne he hasna been heard o’ these twenti year or thereby’ ‘i wot weel it’ no twenti years’ said the landladi ‘it’ no abun seventeen at the outsid in thi veri month 
< it made an unco nois ower a’ thi countri the bairn disappear the veri day that supervisor kennedi cam by hi end 
< if ye kenn’d thi countri lang syne your honour wad mayb ken frank kennedi the supervisor 
< he wa a heartsom pleasant man and compani for the best gentlemen in the counti and muckl mirth he’ made in thi hous 
< i wa young then sir and newli marri to baili maccandlish that’ dead and gone a sigh and muckl fun i’v had wi’ the supervisor 
< he wa a daft dog

1912,1918c1912,1918
< she wa as innoc as gay but unfortun for us both as gay as innoc 
< my own manner were partli form by studi i had forsaken and habit of seclus not quit consist with my situat as command of a regiment in a countri where univers hospit is offer and expect by everi settler claim the rank of a gentleman 
< in a moment of peculiar pressur you know how hard we were sometim run to obtain white face to counten our lineofbattl a young man name brown join our regiment as a volunt and find the militari duti more to hi fanci than commerc in which he had been engag remain with us as a cadet 
< let me do my unhappi victim justic he behav with such gallantri on everi occas that offer that the first vacant commiss wa consid as hi due 
< i wa absent for some week upon a distant expedit when i return i found thi young fellow establish quit as the friend of the hous and habitu attend of my wife and daughter 
< it wa an arrang which displeas me in mani particular though no object could be made to hi manner or charact 
< yet i might have been reconcil to hi familiar in my famili but for the suggest of anoth

> those articl which proper and decent arrang look credit and handsom have then a paltri and wretch appear and the apart strip of all that render them commodi and comfort have an aspect of ruin and dilapid 
> it is disgust also to see the scene of domest societi and seclus thrown open to the gaze of the curious and the vulgar to hear their coars specul and brutal jest upon the fashion and furnitur to which they are unaccustomeda frolicsom humour much cherish by the whiski which in scotland is alway put in circul on such occas 
> all these are ordinari effect of such a scene as ellangowan now present but the moral feel that in this case they indic the total ruin of an ancient and honour famili gave them trebl weight and poignanc 
> it was some time befor colonel manner could find ani one dispos to answer his reiter question concern ellangowan himself 
> at length an old maidserv who held her apron to her eye as she spoke told him ‘the laird was someth better and they hope he would be abl to leav the hous that day 
> miss luci expect the chais everi moment and as the day was fine for the time o’year they had carri him in his easychair up to the green befor the auld castl to be out of the way of this unco spectacle’ thither colonel manner went in quest of him and soon came in sight of the littl group which consist of four person 
> the ascent was steep so that he had time to reconnoitr them as he advanc and to consid in what mode he should make his address 
> mr bertram paralyt and almost incap of move occupi his easychair attir in his nightcap and a loos camlet coat his feet wrap in blanket 
> behind him with his hand cross on the cane upon which he rest stood domini sampson whom manner recognis at onc 
> time had made no chang upon him unless that his black coat seem more brown and his gaunt cheek more lank than when manner last saw him 
> on one side of the old man was a sylphlik forma young woman of about seventeen whom the colonel account to be his daughter 
> she was look from time to time anxious toward the avenu as if expect the postchais and between while busi herself in adjust the blanket so as to protect her father from the cold and in answer inquiri which he seem to make with a captious and querul manner

< in fact he wa too proud a man to be a vain one 
< he resolv therefor to place himself upon the foot of a countri gentleman of easi fortun without assum or permit hi household to assum ani of the fast which then wa consid as characterist of a nabob

> woodbourn the habit which manner by mr macmorlan’ mediat had hire for a season was a larg comfort mansion snug situat beneath a hill cover with wood which shroud the hous upon the north and east the front look upon a littl lawn border by a grove of old tree beyond were some arabl field extend down to the river which was seen from the window of the hous 
> a toler though oldfashion garden a wellstock dovecot and the possess of ani quantiti of ground which the conveni of the famili might requir render the place in everi respect suitabl as the advertis have it ‘for the accommod of a genteel family’ here then manner resolv for some time at least to set up the staff of his rest 
> though an eastindian he was not partial to an ostentati display of wealth 
> in fact he was too proud a man to be a vain one 
> he resolv therefor to place himself upon the foot of a countri gentleman of easi fortun without assum or permit his household to assum ani of the fast which then was consid as characterist of a nabob 
> he had still his eye upon the purchas of ellangowan which macmorlan conceiv mr glossin would be compel to part with as some of the creditor disput his titl to retain so larg a part of the purchasemoney in his own hand and his power to pay it was much question 
> in that case macmorlan was assur he would readili give up his bargain if tempt with someth abov the price which he had stipul to pay 
> it may seem strang that manner was so much attach to a spot which he had onli seen onc and that for a short time in earli life

> the eye agate—a is general appreci the evil eye is the sourc of all troubl and misfortun and the earli eastern race thought that if the evil eye could be avoid or frighten away all would be well 
> search for a charm to effect their purpos they alight upon the eye agat and this they believ would give no quarter to the evil eye 
> accord agat were cut to resembl an eye which would be power enough to neutral the effect of the evil one and these were worn as brooch ring and necklac

> thus by cut the stone oval and removing10 part of the top layer it was possibl to produc a charm close resembl a human eye both in shape and color

> the dragon head when posit in the first hous show poverti in the second a good estat in the third honest kindr and fortun journey in the fourth gain by travel in the fifth long life and good children in the sixth health and good servant in the seventh a virtuous wife in the eighth mani legaci and a natur death in the ninth prosper at sea in the tenth honour in the eleventh faith friend in the twelfth open enemi 
5274,5281c5274,5281
< on form a gener judgment on a nativ respect the distribut of the doctrin of nativ we are to consid first the parent then the durat of life the shape and figur of the bodi after these the qualiti of the mind then as to fortun in regard to honour as well as wealth 
< in success to these the charact of the employ the question rel to marriag children and friendship then that concern travel and lastli that concern the kind of death which await the nativ from the configur of the heaven at hi birth 
< the parents—in conform with natur say ptolemi the sun and saturn are allot to the person of the father and the moon and venu to that of the mother and the mode in which these luminari and planet may be found posit with refer to each other as well as to other planet and star will intim the situat of affair affect the parent 
< if mar should be in bad aspect to the sun the father will receiv some injuri to the face or die suddenli but a long life is presag if jupit or venu be in ani mode whatev configur with either the sun or saturn 
< if mar be succed to the moon or venu or in quartil or opposit to them or if saturn be similarli aspect to the moon onli and both of them be void of cours or retrograd or cadent advers accid and diseas will attend the mother should they on the other hand be swift in motion and place in angl they portend that her life will be short or grievous afflict 
< should the sun be configur in ani mode whatev with the moon or venu or should venu herself be harmoni configur with the moon either by the sextil the trine or the conjunct the mother will live long 
< concern the durat of the nativ own life the hylegliacal9 place are accord to ptolemi the sign on the angl of the ascend from the fifth degre abov the horizon to the twentyfifth degre below it the thirti degre in dexter sextil thereto constitut the eleventh hous also the thirti degre in dexter quartil form the midheaven abov the earth those in dexter trine make the ninth hous and lastli those in opposit belong to the angl of the west 
< among these place the degre which constitut the midheaven are entitl to prefer as be of a more potent influenc the degre in the ascend are next in virtu then the degre in the eleventh hous succed to the midheaven then those in the angl of the west and lastli those in the ninth hous which preced the midheaven 
---
> on form a general judgment on a nativ respect the distribut of the doctrin of nativ we are to consid first the parent then the durat of life the shape and figur of the bodi after these the qualiti of the mind then as to fortun in regard to honour as well as wealth 
> in success to these the charact of the employ the question relat to marriag children and friendship then that concern travel and last that concern the kind of death which await the nativ from the configur of the heaven at his birth 
> the parents—in conform with natur say ptolemi the sun and saturn are allot to the person of the father and the moon and venus to that of the mother and the mode in which these luminari and planet may be found posit with refer to each other as well as to other planet and star will intim the situat of affair affect the parent 
> if mar should be in bad aspect to the sun the father will receiv some injuri to the face or die sudden but a long life is presag if jupit or venus be in ani mode whatev configur with either the sun or saturn 
> if mar be succed to the moon or venus or in quartil or opposit to them or if saturn be similar aspect to the moon onli and both of them be void of cours or retrograd or cadent advers accid and diseas will attend the mother should they on the other hand be swift in motion and place in angl they portend that her life will be short or grievous afflict 
> should the sun be configur in ani mode whatev with the moon or venus or should venus herself be harmoni configur with the moon either by the sextil the trine or the conjunct the mother will live long 
> concern the durat of the nativ own life the hylegliacal9 place are accord to ptolemi the sign on the angl of the ascend from the fifth degre abov the horizon to the twentyfifth degre below it the thirti degre in dexter sextil thereto constitut the eleventh hous also the thirti degre in dexter quartil form the midheaven abov the earth those in dexter trine make the ninth hous and last those in opposit belong to the angl of the west 
> among these place the degre which constitut the midheaven are entitl to prefer as be of a more potent influenc the degre in the ascend are next in virtu then the degre in the eleventh hous succed to the midheaven then those in the angl of the west and last those in the ninth hous which preced the midheaven
